channel.title: Suburban Backyard Astro Sights
channel.description: Recent content on Suburban Backyard Astro Sights

item.title: The March 14 Lunar Eclipse
item.description: We had fine weather here in North Carolina for the Pi Day March eclipse of the moon. Here’s how it looked through my telescope.

item.title: The Butterfly Nebula
item.description: Near the bright star Sadr (grossly over exposed in the image) at the center of the Northern Cross lies the Butterfly Nebula. Its nickname comes from its intricate shape that somewhat resembles a butterfly with its delicate wings outstretched.

item.title: That's a whole LOT of stars
The Skull Nebula
item.description: The Skull Nebula is another example of the remains left by a dying Sun-like star that has cast away its outer layers in a cosmic farewell, leaving behind hot, glowing complex shells of ionized gas. I’ve shared examples before of these so-called planetary nebulae, but the Skull is a particularly appropriate nickname for such an object!

item.title: The Helix Nebula
item.description: The Helix Nebula is a stunning example of a planetary nebula -— a glowing shell of ionized gas expelled by a dying star. The star expels its outer layers of gas, leaving only its small, hot core. Radiation from the core energizes that gas, causing it to glow in a rainbow of colors. About 650 light-years away, the Helix is one of the closest and brightest such nebulae.

item.title: The Heart and Soul of the Night Sky
The Tulip Nebula
item.description: The Tulip Nebula is a glowing cloud of interstellar gas and dust and gets its name from the flower it appears to resemble in photographs. While a pretty sight itself, the Tulip has an interesting neighbor.

item.title: The Trifid Nebula
item.description: The Trifid Nebula, M20, is a beautiful gaseous cloud within which new stars are being born. It is one of several spectacular telescopic sights embedded in the summer and autumn Milky Way.

item.title: The Eagle Nebula
item.description: The Eagle Nebula M16, one of the brightest night sky nebulae, is an area where stars are actively forming. It is filled with dark regions and globules, including a peculiar dark column named the “Stellar Spire”. Of special note are the “Pillars of Creation” made famous by an early (1995) picture from the Hubble Space Telescope. The pillars and spire are collapsing clouds of dust and gas being sculpted by intense starlight from newly formed hot stars.

item.title: The Rosette Nebula
item.description: The Rosette Nebula is one of the more spectacular nebulae in the night sky. It is a huge cloud of glowing gas heated and ionized by stars created only about five million years ago when a giant molecular cloud collapsed to form a new cluster of stars.

item.title: The Odd Couple - Galaxies M82 and M81
item.description: These two spectacular galaxies are neighbors, located near the bowl of the big dipper. M82 is an irregular edge-on galaxy that shows red gas and dark clouds. Its neighbor M81 is face-on, and displays stately grand spiral arms.

item.title: Thor's Helmet
item.description: I never cease to be amazed at the imagination shown by astronomers over the years in coming up with names to attach to celestial nebulae. Here is a look from last week at Thor’s Helmet, a hat shaped emission nebula with wing-like appendages, more formally known as NGC 2359.

item.title: The Triangulum Galaxy
item.description: The Triangulum Galaxy (also known as the Pinwheel Galaxy or M33) is the third largest galaxy in our Local Group of galaxies (after the Milky Way and Andromeda). It is about three million lightyears away from us. Hence we enjoy a better view of it than any other galaxy except Andromeda.

item.title: The Pelican Nebula
item.description: The Pelican Nebula is an emission nebula whose outlines somewhat resemble the namesake bird. The nebula’s appearance is defined by dark dust clouds that outline the pelican’s long bill and eye, and by bright clouds of ionized gas that form the curved shape of the pelican’s head and neck. The pelican’s body and wing are formed by a complex mixture of bright nebulosity intermixed with dark dust clouds, as is the pouch hanging down from the bill.

item.title: Pushing my limits - spotting the James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: Ever since NASA launched their new James Webb Space Telescope last December I’ve been interested in seeing if it was possible to spot it using my 8-inch backyard telescope and camera. Spoiler alert: Yes I can!

item.title: The Orion Nebula and the Running Man
A facelift for our second anniversary
The Horsehead and Flame - the big picture
The Veil Nebula - the big picture
Spiral Galaxies from different angles of view
item.description: Here are three different faint spiral galaxies that look quite different since we view them from different angles.

item.title: The Running Man Nebula
item.description: Following a stretch of poor weather, I got a chance to take the telescope out again the other night and got a good look at a somewhat whimsical space ghost - the Running Man Nebula.

item.title: A Celestial Valentine - The Heart Nebula
item.description: Although I made this picture back in December, I thought it would be appropriate to wait and post it on Valentine’s Day.

item.title: Some Celestial Whimsy
item.description: Here are three somewhat whimsical objects.

item.title: The Christmas Tree Cluster
item.description: Merry Christmas! In keeping with the holiday, here is a fresh look at one of my favorite objects, the Christmas Tree Cluster, NGC 2264.

item.title: Three More Spiral Galaxies
item.description: Here are three attractive galaxies that I was able to observe in the past week or so. You will notice that even though they are all spiral galaxies, they exhibit strikingly different appearance.

item.title: The Pelican Nebula
item.description: The Pelican Nebula (also known as IC 5070) is an emission nebula whose outlines bear a resemblance to a pelican, giving rise to its name.

item.title: Rings in the Sky - Two More Planetary Nebulae
item.description: Here are two of the prettiest nebulae in the sky: the Helix Nebula (NGC7293) and the Ring Nebula (M57).

item.title: The North American Nebula
item.description: The North American Nebula, also known as NGC 7000, is a large emission nebula in the constellation of Cygnus. The name is obvious because the shape of this nebula looks a lot like the continent it was named after.

item.title: The Planet Mars at Its Closest and Finest
item.description: The planet Mars was closer to earth on October 6 than it will be anytime in the next 15 years. The closer it is, the larger it appears and the more detail can be seen. Close also means bright – if you go out in the evening just after dark these days, you will see Mars as the really bright red object in the southeast, brighter and redder than any other star or planet,

item.title: The Planet Jupiter
item.description: Now for something completely different! Normally I spend my time observing “faint fuzzies” as amateur astronomers call dim distant objects. But today I decided to share some images of the planet Jupiter, its Great Red Spot and its equatorial belts that I made on Labor Day weekend.

item.title: The Dumbbell Nebula
item.description: The Dumbbell Nebula M27 (also known as Apple Core Nebula) is a typical planetary nebula about 1300 light-years from us. It was the first such object to be discovered – by Charles Messier in 1764.

item.title: The Trifid Nebula
item.description: The Trifid Nebula, M20, is a beautiful gaseous cloud within which new stars are being born. It is one of several spectacular telescopic sights embedded in the summertime Milky Way.

item.title: Last look at Comet C/2020 F3 NEOWISE
Comet C/2020 F3 NEOWISE
item.description: Now rapidly moving away from both the sun and the earth, Comet NEOWISE (C/2020 F3) was only discovered on March 27 and turned out to be the brightest comet visible from the northern hemisphere since Comet Hale–Bopp in 1997. A week ago it was easily visible to the naked eye, but it has dimmed greatly since then.

item.title: The Lagoon Nebula
item.description: The Lagoon Nebula, M8, is another remarkable region where new stars are being formed. It is a giant glowing cloud of interstellar gas lit up by nearby stars. It is divided by a dark lane of dust and it also contains an embedded cluster NGC 6530 whose stars have been newly formed from the nebular material.

item.title: The Eagle Nebula
item.description: M16, the Eagle Nebula, is one of several spectacular objects now coming into view in the summer evening sky. It has been made famous by the Hubble Space Telescope “Pillars of Creation” photograph - easily the most ubiquitous of all Hubble images.

item.title: Changes and Improvements
item.description: I’d like to call your attention to some changes and improvements to this blog in the past week or so as I try to make the site more enjoyable to browse.

item.title: The Supernova in Galaxy M61 is Hanging in There
item.description: This is an update to my May 16 post. The sky was clear and moonless last Friday night, so I was able to check back in on the M61 supernova. A month later, it has faded only a little bit. I’m happy to report that the “seeing” was better this night, so this image shows somewhat more detail in the galaxy compared to my earlier images.

item.title: A field of galaxies near M49
A New Supernova in Nearby Galaxy M61
item.description: This supernova was discovered on May 6. It is expected to continue to brighten for several days before fading away over several weeks.

item.title: Two Face-on Spiral Galaxies - A Study in Contrasts
Galaxy M83
item.description: Here is a face-on view of the barred spiral galaxy Messier 83, the southern pinwheel galaxy. (It is believed that our own Milky Way galaxy would look very much like M83 if we could view it from outside, although the Milky Way is about twice as large as M83 is.) Notice the bright central nucleus, the well-formed spiral arms, the central bar, and the dark dust lanes.

item.title: The Leo Triplet - Three Galaxies
item.description: The Leo Triplet is an interesting group of three mutually interacting galaxies that are often observed and photographed within a single field of view. The Leo Triplet includes spiral galaxies M65 (lower right), M66 (lower left), and NGC 3628 (upper left). This group of galaxies is found in the constellation Leo, all of them are about 35 million light years from the earth.

item.title: The Christmas Tree Star Cluster
item.description: The Christmas Tree Cluster was named for its triangular shape, formed by a cluster of very young stars, that looks like a tree in visible light. The bright variable star S Monocerotis (near the bottom) marks the base of the Christmas tree and lights up the nearby nebulosity.

item.title: The Horsehead Nebula
item.description: The Horsehead Nebula consists of a cloud of ionized gas lit from within by young, hot stars; a dark cloud containing interstellar dust lies immediately in front. The dust absorbs the light from part of the ionized cloud. A portion of this dark cloud has a shape somewhat resembling a horse’s head. The nebula is located 1,300 light-years from the Sun.

item.title: The Flame Nebula
item.description: The Flame Nebula, designated as NGC 2024, is an emission nebula in the constellation Orion. It is about 900 to 1,500 light-years away.

item.title: The Owl Nebula and Surfboard Galaxy
Galaxies M81 and M82
item.description: Here are two nearby galaxies taken from my back yard with my new astrograph telescope. M81 is face-on and its neighbor M82 is edge-on. Dust clouds in the latter are especially noticeable.

item.title: The Whirlpool Galaxy
item.description: M51, better known as the Whirlpool Galaxy, is a magnificent face-on spiral galaxy. The Whirlpool Galaxy is interacting with a smaller companion, NGC 5195, a dwarf galaxy connected to its larger neighbour by a tidal bridge of dust. The bridge is visible in images of the pair silhouetted against the central region of the smaller galaxy. It lies at an approximate distance of 35 million light years from Earth.
